qas.question: Who was a Sichuan school teacher?

answers.text: that he was being investigated on suspicion of the crime of inciting subversion

qas.question: What did Liu Shankun do with the pictures he took of collapsed schools?
Where did he call the schoolhouses shoddy?

context: Besides parents, <a0_0>Liu Shaokun<a0_0/> (刘绍坤), a <a2_0>Sichuan school teacher<a2_0/>, was detained on June 25, 2008 for "disseminating rumors and destroying social order" about the Sichuan earthquake. Liu’s family was later told <a1_0>that he was being investigated on suspicion of the <a3_0>crime of inciting subversion<a3_0/><a1_0/>. Liu had travelled to the Shifang, taken photos of collapsed school buildings, and <a4_0>put them online<a4_0/>. He had also expressed his anger at “the shoddy tofu-dregs buildings” (豆腐渣工程) <a5_0>in a media interview<a5_0/>. He was ordered to serve <a6_0>one year of re-education<a6_0/> through labor (RTL). According to the organization Human Rights in China, Liu has been released to serve his RTL sentence outside of the labor camp.
